was observed by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-3200FS, JEOL,
Tokyo, Japan). The solution was dried to powder for X-ray di
Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientiﬁc ESCALAB 250
XI, ThermoFisher Scientiﬁc, Waltham, MA, USA). A ﬂuorescence spectrometer (FLS-980, Edinburgh
Instruments, Edinburgh, UK) was used to characterize the ﬂuorescence performances of the SnO
QDs. The wavelength of excitation in ﬂuorescence characterization was 280 nm. The SnO

QDs with heavy metal ion incorporation (
The characterization of ﬂuorescence was carried out immediately after the incorporation. In order to
QDs in the practical detection of heavy metal ions, several types of
background water were employed, namely, deionized water, reclaimed water and sea water. The sea
water was collected from Xinghai Bay of Yellow Sea, Dalian, China. There were no Ni
deionized water and reclaimed water. The reclaimed water contained cations of Fe
L) as well as several anions (
L). The main composition of sea water included
was not taken into account because it was insigniﬁcant
The grain size distribution of the SnO
QDs from DLS is shown in Figure
from 2 to 10 nm. The peak appeared at 5.3 nm and approximate 90% of the grains were of the size
within 4–6 nm. The morphology of the SnO
QDs was observed by HRTEM, as shown in Figure
The prepared QDs have a uniform dispersion in the aqueous solution. The Zeta potential of the
as-prepared sample was 17.3 mV and it was measured to be 17.1 mV after 3 months of storage at room
QDs were stable in the aqueous solution for several months. The average
grain size was measured to be 2.23 nm. The grain sizes of QDs were from 1.4 nm to 3.4 nm, and
over 50% of them were between 2.0 to 2.5 nm. The characteristic spacing of 0.33 nm was observed,
corresponding to the (110) planes of the rutile phase of SnO
QD solution was acquired after the completion of hydrolysis and
oxidation. The grain size and Zeta potential of the SnO
QDs were analyzed by dynamic light
scattering (DLS, Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS 90, Malvern panalytical Ltd., Malvern, UK). The
morphology was observed by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM,
JEM-3200FS, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The solution was dried to powder for X-ray diffraction (XRD,
Rigaku D/MAX-Ultima, Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo
Scientific ESCALAB 250 XI, ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). A fluorescence
spectrometer (FLS-980, Edinburgh Instruments, Edinburgh, UK) was used to characterize the
QDs. The wavelength of excitation in fluorescence
QD solution was diluted to 0.002 mol/L of Sn atoms and it
was incorporated with heavy metal ions of Cd
) was defined as the ratio of the maximum intensity of SnO
. The characterization of fluorescence was carried out
immediately after the incorporation. In order to evaluate the applicability of SnO
practical detection of heavy metal ions, several types of background water were employed, namely,
deionized water, reclaimed water and sea water. The sea water was collected from Xinghai Bay of
Yellow Sea, Dalian, China. There were no Ni
ions in the deionized water and reclaimed water. The
reclaimed water contained cations of Fe
(<0.1 mg/L) as well as several anions
(<1.0 mg/L). The main composition of sea water included cations of Na
(1.33 mg/L) as well as anions of Cl
was not taken into account because it was insignificant compared to other major solutes.
The grain size distribution of the SnO
QDs from DLS is shown in Figure 1. The grain size was
from 2 to 10 nm. The peak appeared at 5.3 nm and approximate 90% of the grains were of the size
within 4–6 nm. The morphology of the SnO
QDs was observed by HRTEM, as shown in Figure 2.
The prepared QDs have a uniform dispersion in the aqueous solution. The Zeta potential of the
as-prepared sample was 17.3 mV and it was measured to be 17.1 mV after 3 months of storage at
QDs were stable in the aqueous solution for several months. The
average grain size was measured to be 2.23 nm. The grain sizes of QDs were from 1.4 nm to 3.4 nm,
and over 50% of them were between 2.0 to 2.5 nm. The characteristic spacing of 0.33 nm was
observed, corresponding to the (110) planes of the rutile phase of SnO
